title: Gap Challenge Solver
text:
Please leave a comment below or give me a starğŸŒŸ at the Github repository if you find this useful.

How to Use the Switch Challenge Solver
Letâ€™s use the most difficult level 5 as an example:

We first change the number of rows and columns of the solver to â€œ5â€:

We then enter the existing patterns using numbers:

Alternatively, we can also snip the patterns from the screen and paste them into the solver:

Then hit Enter (if you are using a computer) or press the Submit button. If the problem is entered correctly, a full solution will be displayed:

In this case, 4, which corresponds to the green trigangle, is the answer we are looking for.
In the end, we can hit ~/` if on a computer, or hit Clear to clear the problem and move on to the next one.

title: Switch Challenge Solver
text:
How to Use the Switch Challenge Solver
There are two ways of using the solver:

Drag and Drop to enter the input and outshapes, then enter the middle part of the formula, which is potentially slower.
Enter the full formula, which can be faster when you are more familiar as you have done more assessments (very bad humour).

Please leave a comment below or give me a starğŸŒŸ at the Github repository if you find this useful.


Using Drag and Drop
Similar to the problems, there are two rows of â€œshapesâ€, the row at the top is the inputs while the other one at the bottom is the outputs. By dragging and dropping the shapes, you can enter the input and output colours.
For the easiest problems (as the one below), once you have moved both rows of shapes, the answer is automatically displayed below the line edit:



Easy problem


PS: to clear the formula and answer, hit the ~/` button
For the harder question, you may need to enter the formula (from level 4 onward?) and hit Enter. In the formula, you need to replace the options with xï¼š



Medium problem


The solver can handle x in any position:



Hard problem


For the hardest questions with two choices, you need to make a guess about the first choice, and let the solver find the second choice. If the answer is not correct, you need to try again. You may need to try 3 times at most:



Hardest problem


In this case, the third option of the first choice is the correct answer. This implies that you need to try 3 times if you do from left to right.


Using the full formula
There are two ways of using the full formula, long form and short form. In both cases, ignore the shapes in the solver, they donâ€™t do anything. You can even check the box at the top to hide the shapes.
In the long form, you enter the input and output colors.
Letâ€™s use the hard case as an example, the formula would be:
ybgr+1324+x+3241=gbyr



Long Formula with GUI


The gist of the short formula form is that you encode the outcome (number after =) in such a way that it is a single switch from the input to the output. Note that you cannot use the short formula for the easiest problems (you solve it with your brain).
Letâ€™s use the hard case as an example:



Short Formula with GUI


You can hide the shapes by checking the box at the top:



Hide shapes

title: Revisiting the Link between Democracy and Terrorism
text:
Abstract
This essay revisits the link between democracy and terrorism. Several related divided conclusions proposed in the past are re-examined with new data. An OLS regression with fixed effects and a 2SLS regression are adopted in this essay. The results confirms the common belief that democracy has a positive curvilinear relationship with terrorism. Countries respecting physical integrity would experience less terrorism. High levels of mobilization would inspire terrorism, and new systematic changes in the dynamic between democracy and terrorism remain to be further explored.




CitationBibTeX citation:@online{fu2024,

  url = {https://bim382.github.io/papers/2024-12-09-Terrorism/},
  langid = {en}
}

title: Accessibility commitment
text: Travel back to the home page or about page.

title: Accessibility commitment
text:
Feedback
I welcome any feedback on the accessibility of my site and/or the educational materials I create. Please let me know if you encounter any accessibility barriers by using my contact form and Iâ€™ll do my best to respond promptly.
Thank you for visiting my site and for taking the time to read this page

title: Accessibility commitment
text:
Accessibility practices
This site has been designed with the following features in mind:

A color palette that meets WCAG 2.1 AA standards for contrast
Alternative text for all informative images
Readable font faces, specifically to avoid impostor letter shapes and mirroring. This site primarily uses Red Hat Text which is freely available and has been found to be relatively accessible to users with dyslexic traits and poor near vision.1
A table of contents in the blog post sidebar for easier navigation

Iâ€™m aware there is much more to inclusive and accessible design and Iâ€™m learning how to implement better accessibility practices in the content I create. Iâ€™m not a web developer but my plan is to regularly audit my site for accessibility failures and learn how to remedy them as best I can. Iâ€™ll be using the following evaluation tools:

WAVE Web Accessibility Evaluation Tool

In addition, Iâ€™ll document the failures and any corrective actions as issues in the GitHub repository housing the files used to build this site.
